overview_of_class: This lecture/discussion on the black freedom struggle from the 1940s through the 1970s, will explore the northern and southern civil rights movements and the rise of the Black Power movement. Emphasis will be on new accounts of the movement that challenge or destabilize the standard narrative.

enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: PRE-REG: Reserved for African American Studies majors & minors.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This lecture/discussion on the black freedom struggle from the 1940s through the 1970s, will explore the northern and southern civil rights movements and the rise of the Black Power movement. Emphasis will be on new accounts of the movement that challenge or destabilize the standard narrative.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings include Danielle McGuire, At the Dark End of the Street: Black Women, Rape and Resistance: A New History of the Civil Rights Movement from Rosa Parks to Black Power and Thomas Sugrue, Sweet Land of Liberty: The Forgotten Struggle for Civil Rights in the North. We will also read classic texts by movement leaders, including Martin Luther King's Where Do We Go From Here?: Chaos or Community and Stokely Carmichael's Black Power: The Politics of Liberation.
